species.name: Koala
species.funFact: Koalas sleep up to 22 hours a day to conserve energy from their low-nutrient eucalyptus diet. Each koala has a unique nose print, like human fingerprints!

species.name: Orange-bellied Parrot
species.funFact: With fewer than 50 individuals left in the wild, every single Orange-bellied Parrot counts. They migrate between Tasmania and mainland Australia—one of only two migratory parrots in the world!

species.name: Northern Quoll
species.funFact: These feisty marsupial carnivores can climb trees and swim! Sadly, they're fatally attracted to cane toads, which are poisonous to them.

species.name: Southern Corroboree Frog
species.funFact: One of the world's most striking frogs with bold yellow and black stripes! Their skin produces a toxin that once protected them—but not from the deadly chytrid fungus.

species.name: Grey Nurse Shark
species.funFact: Despite their fierce appearance, Grey Nurse Sharks are docile and pose no threat to humans. They're the first shark species in the world to be protected!

species.name: Tasmanian Devil
species.funFact: Tasmania's top carnivore has the strongest bite-force-to-body-size ratio of any mammal! They're battling a contagious facial tumor disease that threatens their survival.

species.name: Leadbeater's Possum
species.funFact: Victoria's state emblem lives in old-growth Mountain Ash forests. They nest in tree hollows that take 120+ years to form—logging threatens their last refuges.

species.name: Night Parrot
species.funFact: This mysterious nocturnal parrot was thought extinct for nearly 100 years until rediscovered in 2013. So rare, scientists are still learning where they live!

species.name: Western Swamp Tortoise
species.funFact: One of the world's rarest reptiles, found only in two small swamps near Perth. Climate change and habitat loss threaten their seasonal wetland homes.

species.name: Gouldian Finch
species.funFact: Called the 'Rainbow Bird' for its spectacular colors—purple, yellow, red, green, and blue! Fire regimes and habitat changes have caused drastic population decline.
